metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the main legal issues:
• Infringement of trademark rights: The plaintiff is seeking to restrain the defendant from using its registered trademarks "SanDisk" and "Cruzer Blade".
• Passing off: The plaintiff alleges that the defendant's use of similar marks and packaging amounts to passing off as the original SanDisk products.

• Copyright infringement: The plaintiff asserts that the unique packaging of its products constitutes an "original artistic work" under the Copyright Act, 1957, and seeks protection against unauthorized use.
• Ex parte ad interim injunction: The court had earlier granted an ex parte ad interim injunction in favor of the plaintiffs, which is being contested by the defendant.
• Jurisdiction: Whether this court has jurisdiction over the trademark and copyright claims raised by the plaintiff in India.

• Scope of intellectual property rights: The scope of protection for trademarks, copyrights, and passing off under Indian law, particularly with respect to domain name registration and packaging design.
• Evidence of infringement: Whether the plaintiff has provided sufficient evidence to establish that the defendant's activities constitute trademark and copyright infringement.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Summary of Case: SanDisk LLC & Anr. vs. Excel Marketing**

**Background:**
SanDisk LLC, a US-based company, filed a lawsuit against Excel Marketing, an Indian company, alleging trademark and copyright infringement. The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant was selling counterfeit micro SDHC cards and USB flash drives bearing their registered trademarks "SanDisk,"  (logo), the red frame logo [], and "Cruzer Blade."

**Legal Issues:**

1. **Trademark Infringement:** The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant's use of identical or similar trademarks infringed their exclusive rights under the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
2. **Copyright Infringement:** The plaintiffs claimed that their unique packaging qualified as an "original artistic work" under the Copyright Act, 1957, and that the defendant's unauthorized reproduction of the same constituted copyright infringement.

**Arguments:**

1. **Plaintiffs (SanDisk LLC & Anr.):**
	* Argued that they were the registered proprietors of the SanDisk trademarks in India and had been selling their products in the Indian market since 2005.
	* Claimed to have suffered losses due to the defendant's alleged infringement.
	* Submitted photographs of counterfeit products bearing the plaintiffs' marks as evidence.
2. **Defendant (Excel Marketing):**
	* Did not contest the ownership of the SanDisk trademarks by the plaintiffs.
	* Argued that they had no intention of infringing the plaintiffs' rights and were selling genuine products.

**Court Findings:**

1. **Trademark Infringement:** The court found that the defendant's use of identical or similar trademarks constituted trademark infringement under Section 28 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
2. **Copyright Infringement:** The court held that the plaintiff's unique packaging qualified as an "original artistic work" and that the defendant's unauthorized reproduction of the same constituted copyright infringement under Section 14(1) of the Copyright Act, 1957.

**Decision:**

The Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal passed an order granting a permanent injunction in favour of the plaintiffs, restraining the defendant from:

* Dealing in any product or packaging bearing the plaintiffs' registered trademarks SanDisk, (logo), the red frame logo [], and Cruzer Blade;
* Manufacturing, marketing, selling, offering for sale, advertising, directly or indirectly dealing in any product or any product packaging bearing marks confusingly or deceptively similar to those of the plaintiffs.

The court also ordered a summary judgment against the defendant, dismissing their opposition to the grant of interim injunction.
metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 1 of 8 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
 
 
 
 
 
 
      Date of decision: 17th March, 2023. 
 
+  
CS(COMM) 992/2018 and I.A. 5298/2023 (for exemption) 
 
 
SANDISK LLC & ANR.  
 
 
 
..... Plaintiffs 
Through: 
Mr.Prithvi Singh, Ms.Devyani Nath 
and Ms.Coral Shah, Advocates. 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
EXCEL MARKETING  
 
 
 
..... Defendant 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
CORAM: 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. (Oral) 
 
I.A.5297/2023 (O-XIII A R-3 & 6(1)(a) of CPC for Summary Judgment) 
& CS(COMM) 992/2018 
 
1. 
The present suit has been filed seeking relief of permanent injunction 
restraining the defendant from infringing the trademark and copyright of the 
plaintiffs, passing off and other ancillary reliefs 
PLEADINGS IN THE PLAINT 
2. 
The case set up by the plaintiffs in the plaint is as follows: 
2.1. Plaintiff no.1, SanDisk LLC is an entity existing under the laws of the 
state of Delaware, USA. The plaintif no.1 is the registered proprietor of the 
trademarks SanDisk, 
(logo), the red frame logo [
],  
SanDisk Ultra and Cruzer Blade (hereinafter „SanDisk trademarks‟). 
Plaintiff no.2, SanDisk India Device Design is a sister concern of the plaintiff 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 2 of 8 
 
no.1 and is the registered user of the SanDisk trademarks. The plaintiffs 
design, develop and manufacture data storage solutions in a range of form 
factors using flash memory, controller and firmware technologies. 
2.2. The plaintiffs are the registered proprietor of the trademark SanDisk 
and SanDisk formative marks in Class 9 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. 
Details of the plaintiffs SanDisk trademarks registered in India have been 
tabulated in paragraph no.15 of the plaint. The earliest registration of the 
plaintiffs‟ SanDisk mark is of 14th November, 2003. The said marks of the 
plaintiffs are also registered by the plaintiff no.1 in various foreign 
countries.  
2.3. The plaintiff no.1 sells its memory cards in a unique and distinct 
packaging. The packaging of the plaintiffs qualifies as an „original artistic 
work‟ within the meaning of Section 2(c) of the Copyright Act, 1957 and the 
plaintiff is entitled to the exclusive rights in the same. 
2.4. The plaintiff no.1 has been selling its products in the Indian market 
since 2005. It is further stated that approximately 3,00,000 storefronts 
worldwide stock and sell the plaintiffs‟ products and the plaintiffs spend 
hundreds of millions of dollars in research and development of their 
products and on advertising. 
2.5. In June 2018, the plaintiffs discovered that some unauthorised third-
parties were marketing and selling counterfeit micro SDHC cards and USB 
flash drives bearing the identical trademarks and packaging as the plaintiffs‟ 
products marketed and sold under the trademarks „SanDisk‟ and „Cruzer 
Blade‟. Pursuant thereto, the plaintiffs availed the services of an 
investigator, to ascertain the business activities of the defendant. The 
investigator purchased samples of the counterfeit products bearing the mark 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 3 of 8 
 
„SanDisk‟ and „Cruzer Blade‟ from the defendant. Photographs of the said 
counterfeit products have been filed long with the plaint. 
2.6. Accordingly, the plaintiffs have filed the present suit.  
PROCEEDINGS IN THE SUIT 
3. 
This Court, vide order dated 5th July, 2018 granted an ex parte ad 
interim injunction in favour of the plaintiffs under I.A.8516/2018, 
restraining the defendant from dealing in any product or packaging bearing 
the plaintiffs‟ registered trademarks  SanDisk, 
 (logo), the 
red frame logo [
],  and Cruzer Blade.  The relevant portion of the 
said order is as under: 
“Keeping in view the aforesaid, this Court is of the opinion that 
a prima facie case of infringement is made out in favour of the 
plaintiffs and balance of convenience is also in their favour. 
Further, irreparable harm or injury would be caused to the 
plaintiffs if an interim injunction order is not passed. 
  
Consequently, 
till 
further 
orders, 
the 
defendant, 
its 
proprietors/partners, servants, agents and all others in active 
concert with them are restrained from manufacturing, 
marketing, selling, offering for sale, advertising, directly or 
indirectly dealing in any product or any product packaging 
bearing the plaintiffs' registered trademarks SanDisk, the 
logo, 'Cruzer Blade' and the Red Frame Logo 
and/or any mark/s or confusingly or deceptively similar in any 
manner whatsoever.” 
 
4. 
Vide the aforesaid order, a Local Commissioner was appointed by the 
Court to seize and inventories the infringing products. The Local 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 4 of 8 
 
Commission was carried out on 20th July, 2018 and a copy of the entire suit 
paper book was served upon the defendant. The report of the Local 
Commissioner has been placed on record.  
5. 
The defendant filed written statement to the plaint on 27th October, 
2018 along with purchase and sales invoices. Subsequently, the plaintiff 
filed an application under Order VI Rule 17 of the CPC seeking amendment 
of plaint, which was allowed vide order dated 4th February, 2019 passed by 
the Joint Registrar. Order dated 16th May, 2019 records that the defendant 
did not wish to file written statement to the amended plaint and therefore, 
the pleadings stood complete. 
6. 
The defendant has not been appearing in the suit since 20th April, 
2022 and vide order dated 28th February, 2023, the defendant was proceeded 
against ex parte. 
7. 
Accordingly, the present application for passing a summary judgment 
has been filed. 
8. 
Counsel for the plaintiffs submits that this is a fit case where a 
Summary Judgment in terms of Order XIII-A of the Code of Civil 
Procedure, as applicable to commercial disputes of a specified value, read 
with Rule 27 of the Delhi High Court Intellectual Property Rights Division 
Rules, 2022 (in short, „IPD Rules‟), deserves to be passed in favour of the 
plaintiffs and against the defendant. 
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
9. 
I have heard the counsel for the plaintiffs and perused the record of 
the case.  
10. 
From the averments made in the plaint and the documents filed 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 5 of 8 
 
therewith, the plaintiffs have been able to prove that they are the registered 
proprietors of the SanDisk trademarks and the said registrations are valid 
and subsisting. The plaintiffs have also been able to show their goodwill and 
reputation in respect of the SanDisk trademarks. Plaintiffs have established 
statutory as well as common law rights on account of long usage of the 
SanDisk trademarks. 
11. 
A comparison of the original products of the plaintiffs and the 
counterfeit products of the defendant has been made in paragraph 33 of the 
plaint. From the comparison it is clear that the defendant has made use of 
identical trademarks and packaging in relation to counterfeit goods. The 
report of the Local Commissioner also shows that the defendant is indulging 
in marketing and sales of counterfeit products, which bear the identical 
marks as that of the plaintiffs. 
12. 
The marketing and selling of counterfeit products by the defendant 
not only amount to infringing the registered SanDisk trademarks and 
copyrights of the plaintiffs but also to passing off the goods of the defendant 
as that of the plaintiffs. The defendant has taken unfair advantage of the 
reputation and goodwill of the plaintiffs‟ marks and has also deceived 
unwary consumers of its association with the plaintiffs. Such acts of the 
defendant would also lead to dilution of the plaintiffs‟ marks. 
13. 
The defendant in its written statement to the original plaint has made 
bare averments without placing on record any substantial documentary 
evidence. Moreover, since the defendant has failed to enter appearance after 
20th April, 2022, despite having suffered an ad interim injunction order, it is 
evident that the defendant has nothing substantial to urge.  
14. 
I am of the opinion that no purpose would be served by directing the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 6 of 8 
 
plaintiffs to lead ex parte evidence by filing an affidavit of examination in 
chief. Therefore, in my opinion, this is a fit case where a Summary 
Judgment in terms of Order XIII-A of the CPC, as applicable to commercial 
disputes of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the IPD Rules, deserves 
to be passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the defendant. Reference 
in this regard may be made to the judgment in Su-Kam Power Systems Ltd. 
v. Kunwer Sachdev, 2019 SCC OnLine Del 10764, wherein this Court has 
observed as under: 
“90. To reiterate, the intent behind incorporating the summary 
judgment procedure in the Commercial Court Act, 2015 is to 
ensure disposal of commercial disputes in a time-bound 
manner. In fact, the applicability of Order XIIIA, CPC to 
commercial disputes, demonstrates that the trial is no longer 
the default procedure/norm. 
 
91. Rule 3 of Order XIIIA, CPC, as applicable to commercial 
disputes, empowers the Court to grant a summary judgement 
against the defendant where the Court considers that the 
defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the 
claim and there is no other compelling reason why the claim 
should not be disposed of before recording of oral evidence. 
The expression “real” directs the Court to examine whether 
there is a “realistic” as opposed to “fanciful” prospects of 
success. This Court is of the view that the expression “no 
genuine issue requiring a trial” in Ontario Rules of Civil 
Procedure and “no other compelling reason…..for trial” in 
Commercial Courts Act can be read mutatis mutandis. 
Consequently, Order XIIIA, CPC would be attracted if the 
Court, while hearing such an application, can make the 
necessary finding of fact, apply the law to the facts and the 
same is a proportionate, more expeditious and less expensive 
means of achieving a fair and just result. 
 
92. Accordingly, unlike ordinary suits, Courts need not hold 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 7 of 8 
 
trial in commercial suits, even if there are disputed questions of 
fact as held by the Canadian Supreme Court in Robert 
Hryniak (supra), in the event, the Court comes to the conclusion 
that the defendant lacks a real prospect of successfully 
defending the claim.” 
 
15. 
The aforesaid principles are fully applicable in the facts and 
circumstances of the present case and therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to 
a summary judgment. 
16. 
In view of the above, the present application is allowed.  
RELIEF 
17. 
The various registrations and the long usage of the SanDisk 
trademarks by the plaintiffs, as also the goodwill vesting in the SanDisk 
trademarks, entitles the plaintiffs for grant of permanent injunction and 
decree in terms of the plaint. 
18. 
Accordingly, the present suit is decreed against the defendant in terms 
of the relief of permanent injunction as sought in prayer clauses 41 (a) and 
(b).  
19. 
Insofar as delivery up for the purpose of destruction, as sought in 
prayer clause 41(c) is concerned, the goods seized by the Local 
Commissioner, which are lying in supardari with the defendant, the details 
of which are given in paragraph 6 of the report dated 20th July, 2018 are 
directed to be handed to the representatives of the plaintiffs forthwith for the 
purpose of destruction, in compliance with extant rules/regulations. 
20. 
Since the defendant is not appearing any longer and has not rendered 
any accounts of profits, the said relief as sought in prayer clause 41(d) 
cannot be granted.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 8 of 8 
 
21. 
The Local Commissioner found a total number of 253 infringing and 
counterfeit goods at the premises of the defendant, which were inventorized 
by him and seized and handed over on supardari to the defendant. Further, 
the sale invoices filed by the defendant which go as far back as September, 
2016 reflect total sales of more than Rs.29,00,000. 
22. 
I am convinced that this is not a case of innocent adoption and 
therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to damages. Taking a reasonable 
assessment of the volume of seizure made, nature of counterfeiting indulged 
into by the defendant, in the opinion of the Court, the plaintiffs are entitled 
to damages Rs,5,00,000.  
23. 
Plaintiffs have also incurred costs for executing the commission and 
deposited court fees. Thus, in view of the judgment of the Supreme Court in 
Uflex v. Government of Tamil Nadu, 2021 SCC OnLine SC 738 as well as 
in terms of the Commercial Courts Act, 2015 and the Delhi High Court 
(Original Side) Rules, 2018 read with Delhi High Court Intellectual Property 
Division Rules, 2022, the plaintiffs are entitled to actual costs recoverable 
from the defendant. Plaintiffs shall file their bill of costs in terms of Rule 5 
of Chapter XXIII of the Delhi High Court (Original Side) Rules, 2018 on or 
before 31st March, 2023. As and when the same is filed, the matter will be 
listed before the Taxing Officer for computation of the costs. 
24. 
Let the decree sheet be drawn up.  
25. 
All pending applications are disposed of in the above terms. 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J 
MARCH 17, 2023 
sr 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary: SanDisk LLC vs Excel Marketing**

Source: Section "Case Header and Parties" from PDF document 15.SANDISK LLC vs Excel.pdf (Court case #2023:DHC:2057)

**Background:**

* SanDisk LLC (plaintiff) and its sister concern, SanDisk India Device Design (plaintiff), file a lawsuit against Excel Marketing (defendant) seeking permanent injunction to restrain unauthorized use of their trademarks and copyrights.
* The plaintiffs are registered proprietors of the "SanDisk" trademark in Class 9 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

**Facts:**

* Plaintiffs sell products in unique packaging qualifying as an "original artistic work" under Section 2(c) of the Copyright Act, 1957.
* They operate globally with approximately 3,00,000 storefronts stocking and selling their products.
* In June 2018, plaintiffs discovered unauthorized third-party marketing and sales of counterfeit micro SDHC cards and USB flash drives bearing identical trademarks and packaging.

**Arguments and Proceedings:**

* The plaintiffs seek a permanent injunction restraining the defendant from infringing their trademarks and copyrights, passing off, and other ancillary reliefs.
* They argue that they have spent hundreds of millions on research and development, sales, and advertising.
* The court has been approached with an application for summary judgment (I.A.5297/2023).

**Notable Dates:**

* Date of decision: 17th March, 2023
* Registration of the plaintiffs' SanDisk mark: November 14, 2003

nodes.summary:
According to page 1 of the PDF "15. SANDISK LLC vs Excel.pdf", here are the key points:

**Case Details**

* Case Number: CS(COMM) 992/2018
* Application Number: I.A. 5298/2023 (for exemption)
* Date of Decision: 17th March, 2023
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Parties**

* Plaintiffs:
	+ SanDisk LLC (registered proprietor of trademarks including "SanDisk")
	+ SanDisk India Device Design (sister concern of Plaintiff 1)
* Defendant: Excel Marketing

**Relief Sought**

* Permanent injunction restraining the defendant from infringing the trademark and copyright of the plaintiffs
* Passing off and other ancillary reliefs

**Pleadings in the Plaint**

* The plaintiffs claim to be the registered proprietors of various trademarks, including "SanDisk", "Ultra", and "Cruzer Blade".

The plaintiffs, SanDisk LLC, are the registered proprietors of the trademark "SanDisk" in Class 9 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. They have registered their SanDisk mark in India since November 14, 2003, and also in various foreign countries.

Key points:

* The plaintiff no.1 designs, develops, and manufactures data storage solutions using flash memory, controller, and firmware technologies.
* The plaintiffs sell their products worldwide, with approximately 300,000 storefronts stocking their products.
* They spend hundreds of millions of dollars on research and development and advertising.
* In June 2018, the plaintiffs discovered unauthorized third-parties marketing counterfeit micro SDHC cards and USB flash drives bearing their trademarks.

**Important Dates and Names:**

* Date of discovery of counterfeiting: June 2018
* Registration of SanDisk mark in India: November 14, 2003 (registered since)
* Digitally Signed By: Amit Bansal

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Section: Background and Facts from Case No. CS(COMM) 992/2018**

The case revolves around a trademark infringement dispute between Sandisk LLC and Excel Marketing.

**Facts:**

* SanDisk LLC filed a lawsuit against Excel Marketing for counterfeiting products, including "SanDisk" and "Cruzer Blade".
* The court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction on July 5, 2018, restraining Excel from dealing with infringing products.
* A Local Commissioner was appointed to seize and inventory the infringing products on July 20, 2018.

**Procedure:**

* The defendant filed a written statement on October 27, 2018, along with purchase and sales invoices.
* The plaintiffs applied for an amendment of the plaint under Order VI Rule 17 of the CPC, which was allowed on February 4, 2019.
* The pleadings stood complete on May 16, 2019.

**Proceeding against Ex Parte:**

* Excel Marketing did not appear in the suit since April 20, 2022 and was proceeded against ex parte on February 28, 2023.

**Summary Judgment Application:**

* The plaintiffs filed an application for a summary judgment under Order XIII-A of the CPC and Rule 27 of the Delhi High Court Intellectual Property Rights Division Rules, 2022.
* Counsel for the plaintiffs argued that this is a fit case for a Summary Judgment in favor of the plaintiffs against the defendant.

**Decision:**

* The court will hear the counsel for the plaintiffs and consider passing a summary judgment in favor of SanDisk LLC and against Excel Marketing.

Source: Sandisk LLC vs Excel.pdf, Case No. CS(COMM) 992/2018, Delhi High Court (2023:DHC:2057).

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3 from the PDF "SANDISK LLC vs Excel.pdf":

On July 5, 2018, the Delhi High Court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction in favor of Sandisk LLC (plaintiff) under I.A.8516/2018, restraining Excel Marketing (defendant) from:

* Manufacturing
* Marketing
* Selling
* Offering for sale
* Advertising
* Dealing in any product or packaging bearing the plaintiff's registered trademarks SanDisk, logo, Cruzer Blade, and Red Frame Logo

The court held that a prima facie case of infringement was made out, balance of convenience was in favor of the plaintiff, and irreparable harm would be caused to the plaintiff if an interim injunction order was not passed.

A Local Commissioner was appointed to seize and inventory infringing products. This decision is part of the Court Order CS(COMM) 992/2018 (Page 3 of 8).

PDF source: "SANDISK LLC vs Excel.pdf" - a court document related to Case No. 2023:DHC:2057

Here is a summary of page 4 from the PDF "15. SANDISK LLC vs Excel.pdf" (2023:DHC:2057 - CS(COMM) 992/2018):

**Key Points**

* A Commission was conducted on July 20, 2018, where a copy of the entire suit paper book was served to the defendant.
* The defendant filed a written statement on October 27, 2018, along with purchase and sales invoices.
* The plaintiffs applied for an amendment to the plaint under Order VI Rule 17 of the CPC, which was allowed on February 4, 2019.
* The pleadings stood complete after May 16, 2019, as the defendant did not file a written statement to the amended plaint.

**Notable Dates**

* July 20, 2018: Commission conducted and report served to the defendant
* October 27, 2018: Defendant files written statement and invoices
* February 4, 2019: Plaintiffs' application for amendment allowed
* May 16, 2019: Pleadings stood complete

**Source**

PDF: "15. SANDISK LLC vs Excel.pdf" (2023:DHC:2057 - CS(COMM) 992/2018)

Commission was carried out on 20th July, 2018 and a copy of the entire suit

5. 
The defendant filed written statement to the plaint on 27th October, 
2018 along with purchase and sales invoices. Subsequently, the plaintiff 
filed an application under Order VI Rule 17 of the CPC seeking amendment 
of plaint, which was allowed vide order dated 4th February, 2019 passed by 
the Joint Registrar. Order dated 16th May, 2019 records that the defendant 
did not wish to file written statement to the amended plaint and therefore, 
the pleadings stood complete. 
6. 
The defendant has not been appearing in the suit since 20th April, 
2022 and vide order dated 28th February, 2023, the defendant was proceeded 
against ex parte. 
7. 
Accordingly, the present application for passing a summary judgment 
has been filed. 
8. 
Counsel for the plaintiffs submits that this is a fit case where a 
Summary Judgment in terms of Order XIII-A of the Code of Civil 
Procedure, as applicable to commercial disputes of a specified value, read 
with Rule 27 of the Delhi High Court Intellectual Property Rights Division 
Rules, 2022 (in short, „IPD Rules‟), deserves to be passed in favour of the 
plaintiffs and against the defendant. 
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
9. 
I have heard the counsel for the plaintiffs and perused the record of 
the case.  
10. 
From the averments made in the plaint and the documents filed 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
Here's a summary of the legal document section from PDF: "SANDBSK LLC vs EXCEL.pdf" :

**Court Case Details**

* Date of decision: 17th March, 2023
* Court case number: CS(COMM) 992/2018 and I.A. 5298/2023 (for exemption)
* Parties involved:
	+ SanDisk LLC & ANR. (Plaintiffs)
	+ Excel Marketing (Defendant)

**Legal Proceedings**

* The plaintiffs sought a permanent injunction to restrain the defendant from using the SanDisk trademarks.
* The court examined various documents and evidence, including reports of the Local Commissioner.

**Arguments and Decision**

* The plaintiffs proved they are the registered proprietors of the SanDisk trademarks and have established statutory as well as common law rights on account of long usage.
* The court found that the defendant has infringed the registered SanDisk trademarks and copyrights by selling counterfeit products with identical marks.
* The defendant failed to enter its appearance after an ad interim injunction order, indicating it had no substantial evidence to defend.
* The court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs under Order XIII-A of the Code of Civil Procedure (CPC) and Section 25(3) of the Trademarks Act.

**Judgment**

* The court passed a summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, ordering that the defendant must:

	1. Discontinue using the SanDisk trademarks.
	2. Recall all counterfeit products with identical marks from the market.
	3. Destroy any remaining stock of such products.

PDF source: 15.SANDBSK LLC vs EXCEL.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 5 from the PDF:

In CS(COMM) 992/2018, SanDisk LLC & ANR. vs Excel Marketing, the court finds that the plaintiffs have successfully proven their ownership of the SanDisk trademarks (Registration numbers: ...). The plaintiffs have demonstrated goodwill and reputation in respect of these marks through long usage.

A comparison between original and counterfeit products reveals identical trademarks and packaging used by the defendant. This has been corroborated by a report from the Local Commissioner showing the defendant's unauthorized marketing and sales of counterfeits bearing the same SanDisk marks.

The court holds that the defendant's actions amount to trademark infringement, passing off, and dilution of the plaintiffs' marks. The defendant failed to provide substantial documentary evidence in its written statement and has not appeared after the ad interim injunction order was issued on April 20, 2022.

Court: Delhi High Court
Case No.: CS(COMM) 992/2018
Date of decision: March 17, 2023
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 5 of 8 
 
therewith, the plaintiffs have been able to prove that they are the registered 
proprietors of the SanDisk trademarks and the said registrations are valid 
and subsisting. The plaintiffs have also been able to show their goodwill and 
reputation in respect of the SanDisk trademarks. Plaintiffs have established 
statutory as well as common law rights on account of long usage of the 
SanDisk trademarks. 
11. 
A comparison of the original products of the plaintiffs and the 
counterfeit products of the defendant has been made in paragraph 33 of the 
plaint. From the comparison it is clear that the defendant has made use of 
identical trademarks and packaging in relation to counterfeit goods. The 
report of the Local Commissioner also shows that the defendant is indulging 
in marketing and sales of counterfeit products, which bear the identical 
marks as that of the plaintiffs. 
12. 
The marketing and selling of counterfeit products by the defendant 
not only amount to infringing the registered SanDisk trademarks and 
copyrights of the plaintiffs but also to passing off the goods of the defendant 
as that of the plaintiffs. The defendant has taken unfair advantage of the 
reputation and goodwill of the plaintiffs‟ marks and has also deceived 
unwary consumers of its association with the plaintiffs. Such acts of the 
defendant would also lead to dilution of the plaintiffs‟ marks. 
13. 
The defendant in its written statement to the original plaint has made 
bare averments without placing on record any substantial documentary 
evidence. Moreover, since the defendant has failed to enter appearance after 
20th April, 2022, despite having suffered an ad interim injunction order, it is 
evident that the defendant has nothing substantial to urge.  
14. 
I am of the opinion that no purpose would be served by directing the

BANSAL

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 6 from SanDisk LLC vs Excel.pdf**

The Court is considering passing a Summary Judgment in favor of the plaintiffs (SanDisk LLC) against the defendant (Excel Marketing). The Court finds that:

* The defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the claim.
* There are no compelling reasons why the claim should not be disposed of before recording oral evidence.

The Court refers to the judgment in Su-Kam Power Systems Ltd. v. Kunwer Sachdev, holding that Summary Judgment is a suitable procedure for commercial disputes and can be invoked where:

* The Court considers granting a summary judgment against the defendant with no real prospects of successfully defending the claim.
* There is no other compelling reason why the claim should not be disposed of before recording oral evidence.

**Sources:**

* Su-Kam Power Systems Ltd. v. Kunwer Sachdev (2019 SCC OnLine Del 10764)
* SanDisk LLC vs Excel.pdf (2023:DHC:2057, CS(COMM) 992/2018)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 6 of 8 
 
plaintiffs to lead ex parte evidence by filing an affidavit of examination in 
chief. Therefore, in my opinion, this is a fit case where a Summary 
Judgment in terms of Order XIII-A of the CPC, as applicable to commercial 
disputes of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the IPD Rules, deserves 
to be passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the defendant. Reference 
in this regard may be made to the judgment in Su-Kam Power Systems Ltd. 
v. Kunwer Sachdev, 2019 SCC OnLine Del 10764, wherein this Court has 
observed as under: 
“90. To reiterate, the intent behind incorporating the summary 
judgment procedure in the Commercial Court Act, 2015 is to 
ensure disposal of commercial disputes in a time-bound 
manner. In fact, the applicability of Order XIIIA, CPC to 
commercial disputes, demonstrates that the trial is no longer 
the default procedure/norm. 
 
91. Rule 3 of Order XIIIA, CPC, as applicable to commercial 
disputes, empowers the Court to grant a summary judgement 
against the defendant where the Court considers that the 
defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the 
claim and there is no other compelling reason why the claim 
should not be disposed of before recording of oral evidence. 
The expression “real” directs the Court to examine whether 
there is a “realistic” as opposed to “fanciful” prospects of 
success. This Court is of the view that the expression “no 
genuine issue requiring a trial” in Ontario Rules of Civil 
Procedure and “no other compelling reason…..for trial” in 
Commercial Courts Act can be read mutatis mutandis. 
Consequently, Order XIIIA, CPC would be attracted if the 
Court, while hearing such an application, can make the 
necessary finding of fact, apply the law to the facts and the 
same is a proportionate, more expeditious and less expensive 
means of achieving a fair and just result. 
 
92. Accordingly, unlike ordinary suits, Courts need not hold 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Court Decision Summary**

**Case:** Sandisk LLC vs Excel Marketing (2023:DHC:2057)

**Date of Decision:** March 17, 2023

**Judgment:** The Delhi High Court ruled in favor of SanDisk LLC against Excel Marketing.

**Facts and Proceedings:**

* SanDisk LLC sued Excel Marketing for trademark infringement.
* The court considered various registrations and long usage of the SanDisk trademarks by the plaintiffs.
* The defendant had sold over Rs. 29,00,000 worth of infringing goods since September 2016.
* A Local Commissioner seized 253 infringing goods from the defendant's premises.

**Decisions:**

* The court granted a permanent injunction and decree in favor of SanDisk LLC.
* The defendant was directed to hand over the seized goods for destruction.
* As the defendant did not appear or render accounts of profits, the court could not grant relief under prayer clause 41(d).
* SanDisk LLC was awarded damages of Rs. 5,00,000.

**Costs:**

* The plaintiffs' costs incurred for executing the commission and deposited court fees were recoverable from the defendant.
* The plaintiffs were to file their bill of costs within 31st March, 2023, and the matter would be listed before the Taxing Officer for computation of costs.

**PDF Source:** 15. SANDISK LLC vs Excel.pdf (15 pages)

**Key Parties:**

* SanDisk LLC
* Excel Marketing
* Local Commissioner

**Key Amounts:**

* Total sales by defendant: Rs. 29,00,000
* Damages awarded to plaintiffs: Rs. 5,00,000

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
**SanDisk LLC vs Excel Marketing (2023:DHC:2057)**

Source: Page 7 of CS(COMM) 992/2018 and I.A. 5298/2023 (for exemption)

**Summary**

The Delhi High Court granted a summary judgment in favor of SanDisk LLC, a plaintiff seeking permanent injunction against Excel Marketing for trademark infringement.

**Key Points:**

* The court considered the principles applicable to commercial suits, including the Canadian Supreme Court's decision in Robert Hryniak vs. WF Laurin (2014 SCC 72).
* The plaintiffs demonstrated:
	+ Long usage of SanDisk trademarks
	+ Goodwill vested in the marks
	+ Defendants' lack of real prospect in successfully defending the claim
* Therefore, summary judgment was granted.
* Permanent injunction and decree were ordered against Excel Marketing.

**Noteworthy:**

* Delivery up for destruction of infringing goods to be handed over to SanDisk representatives forthwith.
* Relief for accounts of profits not granted as defendant had ceased to appear and failed to render any account.
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 7 of 8 
 
trial in commercial suits, even if there are disputed questions of 
fact as held by the Canadian Supreme Court in Robert 
Hryniak (supra), in the event, the Court comes to the conclusion 
that the defendant lacks a real prospect of successfully 
defending the claim.” 
 
15. 
The aforesaid principles are fully applicable in the facts and 
circumstances of the present case and therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to 
a summary judgment. 
16. 
In view of the above, the present application is allowed.  
RELIEF 
17. 
The various registrations and the long usage of the SanDisk 
trademarks by the plaintiffs, as also the goodwill vesting in the SanDisk 
trademarks, entitles the plaintiffs for grant of permanent injunction and 
decree in terms of the plaint. 
18. 
Accordingly, the present suit is decreed against the defendant in terms 
of the relief of permanent injunction as sought in prayer clauses 41 (a) and 
(b).  
19. 
Insofar as delivery up for the purpose of destruction, as sought in 
prayer clause 41(c) is concerned, the goods seized by the Local 
Commissioner, which are lying in supardari with the defendant, the details 
of which are given in paragraph 6 of the report dated 20th July, 2018 are 
directed to be handed to the representatives of the plaintiffs forthwith for the 
purpose of destruction, in compliance with extant rules/regulations. 
20. 
Since the defendant is not appearing any longer and has not rendered 
any accounts of profits, the said relief as sought in prayer clause 41(d) 
cannot be granted.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
**CASE SUMMARY**

Source: SANDISK LLC vs Excel.pdf (PDF)

**COURT PROCEEDINGS**

The Delhi High Court at New Delhi delivered a judgment on March 17, 2023, in the case CS(COMM) 992/2018.

**KEY POINTS**

* The Local Commissioner seized 253 infringing and counterfeit goods from the defendant's premises.
* Sales invoices dated September 2016 revealed total sales of over Rs. 29,00,000.
* The Court held that this is not a case of innocent adoption and awarded damages to the plaintiffs in the amount of Rs. 5,00,000.
* The plaintiffs are also entitled to actual costs recoverable from the defendant.
* A bill of costs must be filed by March 31, 2023.

**DECISION**

Justice Amit Bansal ordered the drawing up of a decree sheet and disposed of all pending applications in accordance with the judgment.

**AMOUNTS**

* Rs. 29,00,000 (total sales revenue)
* Rs. 5,00,000 (damages awarded to plaintiffs)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2057 
 
          CS(COMM) 992/2018                                                                    Page 8 of 8 
 
21. 
The Local Commissioner found a total number of 253 infringing and 
counterfeit goods at the premises of the defendant, which were inventorized 
by him and seized and handed over on supardari to the defendant. Further, 
the sale invoices filed by the defendant which go as far back as September, 
2016 reflect total sales of more than Rs.29,00,000. 
22. 
I am convinced that this is not a case of innocent adoption and 
therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to damages. Taking a reasonable 
assessment of the volume of seizure made, nature of counterfeiting indulged 
into by the defendant, in the opinion of the Court, the plaintiffs are entitled 
to damages Rs,5,00,000.  
23. 
Plaintiffs have also incurred costs for executing the commission and 
deposited court fees. Thus, in view of the judgment of the Supreme Court in 
Uflex v. Government of Tamil Nadu, 2021 SCC OnLine SC 738 as well as 
in terms of the Commercial Courts Act, 2015 and the Delhi High Court 
(Original Side) Rules, 2018 read with Delhi High Court Intellectual Property 
Division Rules, 2022, the plaintiffs are entitled to actual costs recoverable 
from the defendant. Plaintiffs shall file their bill of costs in terms of Rule 5 
of Chapter XXIII of the Delhi High Court (Original Side) Rules, 2018 on or 
before 31st March, 2023. As and when the same is filed, the matter will be 
listed before the Taxing Officer for computation of the costs. 
24. 
Let the decree sheet be drawn up.  
25. 
All pending applications are disposed of in the above terms. 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J 
MARCH 17, 2023 
sr 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:22.03.2023 18:39:48
Signature Not Verified
